DANTROLENE SODIUM

  • Indications and doses
  • Drug action
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Important safety information
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Malignant hyperthermia,

By rapid intravenous injection

  • For adults
    Initially 2–3 mg/kg, then 1 mg/kg, repeated if necessary; maximum 10 mg/kg per course.

Chronic severe spasticity of voluntary muscle,

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 25 mg daily, then increased to up to 100 mg 4 times a day, dose increased at weekly intervals; usual dose 75 mg 3 times a day.

Drug action

Acts on skeletal muscle cells by interfering with calcium efflux, thereby stopping the contractile process.

Advice when patient is pregnant

With intravenous use

Use only if potential benefit outweighs risk.

With oral use

Avoid use in chronic spasticity—embryotoxic in animal studies.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Avoid—may cause severe liver damage (injection may be used in an emergency for malignant hyperthermia).

Contra indications

Known side effects

Specific side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: abdominal pain, anorexia, asthenia, chills, diarrhoea (withdraw if severe, discontinue treatment if recurs on re-introduction), dizziness, drowsiness, fatigue, fever, headache, hepatotoxicity, nausea, pericarditis, pleural effusion, rash, respiratory depression, seizures, speech disturbances, visual disturbances, vomiting,

uncommon: confusion, constipation, crystalluria, depression, dysphagia, dyspnoea, erratic blood pressure, exacerbation of cardiac insufficiency, haematuria, increased sweating, increased urinary frequency, insomnia, nervousness, tachycardia, urinary incontinence, urinary retention,

notKnown: dizziness, erythema, hepatotoxicity, injection-site reactions, pulmonary oedema, rash, swelling, thrombophlebitis, weakness,

Hepatotoxicity

Potentially life-threatening hepatotoxicity reported—discontinue if abnormal liver function tests or symptoms of liver disorder; re-introduce only if complete reversal of hepatotoxicity.

Advice for patients and carers

With oral use

Hepatotoxicity

Patients should be told how to recognise signs of liver disorder and advised to seek prompt medical attention if symptoms such as anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, abdominal pain, dark urine, or pruritus develop.

Important safety information

Should only be administered by, or under the direct supervision of, personnel experienced in the use of dantrolene when used for malignant hyperthermia.

Cautions regarding administration

  • With intravenous use: avoid extravasation (risk of tissue necrosis)
  • With oral use: females (hepatotoxicity)
  • With oral use: history of liver disorders (hepatotoxicity)
  • With oral use: if doses greater than 400 mg daily (hepatotoxicity)
  • With oral use: impaired cardiac function
  • With oral use: impaired pulmonary function
  • With oral use: patients over 30 years (hepatotoxicity)
  • With oral use: therapeutic effect may take a few weeks to develop— discontinue if no response within 6–8 weeks

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

With oral use

Test liver function before and at intervals during therapy.

Prepared medicinal forms of DANTROLENE SODIUM

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral solution, oral suspension,
Capsule
Powder for solution for injection
